symptoms.name: Trypanosomal chancre
symptoms.pattern: Appears at the site of the tsetse fly bite within a few days to 2 weeks; evolves into a red, painful, indurated nodule that may ulcerate.

symptoms.name: Intermittent fever
symptoms.pattern: Develops over several months in T. b. gambiense infection, weeks in T. b. rhodesiense; irregular pattern over many weeks.

symptoms.name: Headache
symptoms.pattern: Present in both early and late stages; can be persistent in CNS involvement.

symptoms.name: Transient edema
symptoms.pattern: Facial swelling, can be present in the hemolymphatic stage.

symptoms.name: Generalized lymphadenopathy
symptoms.pattern: Often occurs; Winterbottom's sign (enlarged lymph nodes in the posterior cervical triangle) is characteristic with T. b. gambiense.

symptoms.name: Skin rash
symptoms.pattern: Evanescent, circinate erythematous rash; more readily visible in light-skinned patients.

symptoms.name: Hepatosplenomegaly
symptoms.pattern: Common in early stages, especially in West African trypanosomiasis.

symptoms.name: Daytime somnolence
symptoms.pattern: Develops in the second stage (CNS involvement); progresses to a terminal somnolent state.

symptoms.name: Mental changes
symptoms.pattern: Reduced higher mental functions, difficulty in concentration, inability to cope with surroundings; progresses to coma.

symptoms.name: Tremor
symptoms.pattern: Present in the late stage (CNS involvement).

symptoms.name: Ataxia
symptoms.pattern: Present in the late stage (CNS involvement).

vital_signs.blood_pressure: May be affected in severe cases due to myocardial involvement

physical_findings: Neurological signs in late stages (tremor, ataxia, somnolence)

lab_values.blood_smear: Presence of trypanosomes (often low concentration, requiring concentration techniques)
lab_values.cerebrospinal_fluid: Increased lymphocyte count (≥6 cells/mcL), increased protein levels, presence of trypanosomes, Mott cells
lab_values.serum_immunoglobulins: Markedly elevated serum levels of polyclonal IgM

risk_factors: Residence in or travel to rural sub-Saharan Africa
Contact with infected animals (especially for T. b. rhodesiense)

required: Identification of trypanosomes in blood, lymph node aspirate, or cerebrospinal fluid
supportive: Clinical symptoms (fever, headache, lymphadenopathy, neurological signs)
Positive serological tests (for T. b. gambiense)
